ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: See below- Question 14.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The way Marjorie brought in her own current/past experiences to supplement the material and give real-life examples of land use law in action.

The best aspects of this course were (1) the diverse interest and experience of the students in the class, who brought their perspectives to the class discussions, and (2) the vast experience and complex perspective of the instructor.
Shansky
Marjorie is a delightful person is clearly passionate and incredibly knowledgable about the subject matter.

Professor Shansky's lectures ground the material we are reading for class with ancedotes of examples from her profession experience. This really enhanced my uptake of the material and helped my understand the utility of this course.
Hearing Marjorie's stories of being a land use lawyer. Love the practitioner's perspective.

The best part about this course was the energy and enthusiasm that the professor brought to each and every class. The instructor is extremely passionate about land use law, and this made each class extremely interesting and engaging. Also, the instructor works full time as an attorney, and her experiences serve to bring the material to life. The class was a great mix of case law, conceptual frameworks, and illustrative anecdotes, which made for a well-rounded examination of land use law in an environmental context.

Detailed explanations of ways local, state, and national legal cases affect environmental land use (with a strong emphasis on local levels, like planning and zoning board processes) helped show ways that law can help/hinder environmental management. It was excellent to get this information from a local expert in the field, and follow along with her pertinent cases as they unraveled.

I feel that much of the content of the course should be required to enable better, more informed civic engagement! Marjorie is a delight. Though the presentation of information may not always be linear (not a critique, in my book), it promises to be interesting, considered, and provocative to help me crystallize my own opinions/ideas

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: We barely discussed the cases, and when we did, we gave most of them a surface-level reading. We should have spent more time on these!
I would have appreciated more field trips to witness land use law in practice.
I would have really appreciated a more comprehensive introduction to the subject matter before jumping into cases.I also found it really hard to predict where we were on the syllabus.
Use more powerpoint presentations. A couple field trips to planning meetings would be great!

The class could use greater accountability to ensure that everyone in the class does the readings. I often felt that classes could have been more productive if there were more of an incentive for students to read and annotate each case.

A pointed summary of why certain cases we were assigned to read were/are important to environmental management today would have been helpful. We covered this information in class, but the cases were so multifaceted that a one to three sentence "take-aways" summary at the end of each case reading would have clarified complex cases.

Reading cases can be somewhat dry and hard to muster the effort, but it's good practice and this is one of the most friendly ways to learn to do so! Also, they (we) get better as the semester continues

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: They were great! I would just add a little more structure, limiting student preparation time to about five minutes.
n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Understanding the law behind land use actions is critical for lawyers, planners, and other fields that work in the local land use sector. I think this class fills an absolutely crucial niche for gaining a well-rounded understanding of land use.
This course was very useful to me, for I want to be an urban planner and developer. I appreciated having an option of a legal class within my field instead of land use law.
I have no experience in law and am interested in planning and water resources.
Land use law is important to any aspect of environmental work. I think a lot of change can happen at the local level... and I am excited to learn more!

As someone interested in urban forestry and social justice, this class was very useful. It helped me to better understand both the opportunities and the challenges to using land in an environmentally responsible and socially equitable manner.

The legal system controls many aspects of what an environmental manager can and can not do in lands conservation, and this class showed the specific ways that system can be formed and manipulated to achieve conservation goals, even in the midst of heavy pushes for new developments.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As part of my land use and planning concentration.
I took this course to learn more about land use law and local land use issues. These are important issues for journalists, especially urban/metro reporters, to know about.
This course was very useful to me, for I want to be an urban planner and developer. I appreciated having an option of a legal class within my field instead of land use law.

To learn more about the intricacies of the land use system in the US. To answer questions like: How cities are planned? How zoning developed? What is the relationship between zoning and planning? What tools are available to shift land use practices in new directions?
I am interested law... and Marjorie is so great!

I took this course to better understand how land use planning and zoning affects the protection and distribution of natural resources. I was particularly interested in learning more about who drives the planning process, who the various interests in the process are, and how the process affects the residents of disadvantaged neighborhoods.
Legal/policy background and perspective to incorporate conservation values into residental/urban developments.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely, Marjorie explained everything very well and clearly and always took the time to make sure the class (who all come from very different backgrounds- lawyers, scientists, engineers, etc) understood legal concepts. The knowledge of Connecticut land use law that I gained during this course was extremely helpful to me this semester and will continue to serve me well into the future, as I am considering doing legal work in CT.
Yes!

I feel like I don't know as much about the process of land use regulation as I hoped I would, but I do know that it's a very localized process, so I'm not sure I could have learned that much more without the knowledge being highly specific to a certain geographic area that may or may not be relevant to me.
Yes!
Unfortunately, I don't think I took as much knowledge away with me from this course as I expected.
Yes. My improved understanding the land use system will help me in my personal and professional life.
Yes!
Yes, the course met my expectations.

Yes. It also spurred greater thinking and effort on my part as to how local (and state, federal) land use affect my area of interest. I dove into this deeper through private meetings with Ms. Shanksy and on the final paper, and this subject has now become one of the guiding projects in my studies. I will be presenting on it in an upcoming national conference, and I doubt that would have happened without this class. In summary--the course sparked my thinking, research, and action regarding my area of interest.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You should absolutely take this class. Don't be daunted by the legal textbook, Marjorie understands that everyone approaches the material from a different background and is extremely patient and well-equipped to answer all questions.

This course will expose you to the vast and complicated world of land use law - if you learn nothing else you will learn how vast and complicated it is! Take this course if you're interested in doing anything related to the land...anything relating to building, preservation/conservation, activism, etc. - you will learn how to navigate the legal system.
Take this course!
Ask Marjorie what readings should be completed for the next week. Ask questions when you don't understand. Do some (but not all of the reading)
Do the readings and ask questions. The lectures are organic and responsive to the questions of students in the course so be prepared to participate.
Take it!

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the legal processes and precedents governing the establishment and the adjustment of land use. The class requires an average amount of work, and the final project allows each student to pursue a topic of interest to him or her. This contributed a great deal to what I took away from this class!
Go in with a clear idea of what you want out of the class.
Read the cases and make class interesting for yourself (and others!)
